content.text:
# List of presidents of Syria__disambig_1

This is a list of presidents of Syria since 1922.
List of officeholders
Syria (1922–1958)

| rowspan="2" |
! style="background:;" |
| National Bloc
| rowspan="2" | Quwatli was ousted from power in the March 1949 coup d'état by Husni al-Za'im, his chief of staff.
|-
! style="background:;" |
| National Party
|-
| colspan="10"| Vacant ( – )
|-
! 9
|
| Husni al-Za'im
| 1949
| 26 June 1949
| 14 August 1949
|
! style="background:;" |
| Independent
| Za'im was from 30 March 194926 June 1949 de facto leader as Commander-in-Chief of the Army and Armed Forces. He was overthrown in the August 1949 coup d'état led by Adib Shishakli, and was later executed on the orders of the new government.
|-style="background-color:#E6E6AA"
| —
|
| Sami al-Hinnawi
| —
| 14 August 1949
| 15 August 1949
|
! style="background:;" |
| Military
| Acting President as Commander-in-Chief of the Army and Armed Forces.
|-
| colspan="10"| Vacant ( – )
|-style="background-color:#E6E6AA"
! (4)
|
| Hashim al-Atassi
| 1949
| 19 December 1949
| 5 September 1950
|
! style="background:;" |
| People's Party
| Head of State. During this period, Hinnawi served as the country's de facto leader (as Chairman of the Supreme Council of War) until his overthrow in the December 1949 coup d'état, led by Shishakli, who then became de facto leader as head of the Council of Colonels (later the Supreme Military Council).
|-
! colspan="10"| Second Syrian Republic (1950–1958)
|-
! (4)
|
| Hashim al-Atassi
| 1950
| 5 September 1950
| 2 December 1951
|
! style="background:;" |
| People's Party
| Atassi resigned in the aftermath of the 1951 coup d'état.
|-style="background-color:#E6E6AA"
| —
|
| Adib Shishakli
| —
| 2 December 1951
| 3 December 1951
|
! style="background:;" |
| Syrian Social Nationalist Party
| Acting President as Chief of the General Staff and head of the Supreme Military Council.
|-
! 10
|
| Fawzi Selu
| —
| 3 December 1951
| 11 July 1953
|
! style="background:;" |
| Military
| After the coup the Army Command Council announced that it was collectively assuming responsibility for government, entrusted Selu with all executive and legislative powers, and dissolved the parliament. Shishakli assumed supreme command in the country and took the office of deputy chief of staff.
|-
! 11
|
| Adib Shishakli
| 1953
| 11 July 1953
| 25 February 1954
|
! style="background:;" |
| Arab Liberation Movement
| Shishakli resigned from office in the evening of 26 February 1954, amidst a coup d'état. He fled the country, claiming that he did not want Syria to fall into a civil war.
|-style="background-color:#E6E6AA"
| —
|
| Maamun al-Kuzbari

| 28 February 1954

! style="background:;" |

|-
! colspan="10"| Syrian Arab Republic (1961–present)
|-
| bgcolor=#EEEEEE colspan="10"| Second Syrian Republic (1961–1963)
|-
| colspan="10"| Vacant ( – )
|-
! 13
|
| Nazim al-Qudsi
| 1961
| 14 December 1961
| 8 March 1963
|
! style="background:;" |
| People's Party
| The 1963 coup d'état, an event known as the March 8 Revolution, toppled Qudsi and brought the National Council for the Revolutionary Command (NCRC) to government, although real power lay with the Ba'athist Military Committee, which organized the coup.
|-
| bgcolor=#EEEEEE colspan="10"| Ba'athist Syria (1963–2024)
|-
| colspan="10"| Vacant ( – )
|-
! 14
|
| Lu'ay al-Atassi
| —
| 9 March 1963
| 27 July 1963
|
! style="background:;" |
| Independent
| Atassi was appointed president by the NCRC because he posed no threat to the Military Committee's power. He resigned after high-ranking non-Ba'athist officers were purged.
|-
! 15
|
| Amin al-Hafiz
| —
| 27 July 1963
| 23 February 1966
|
! style="background:;" |
| Ba'ath Party
| Hafiz was overthrown by the Military Committee because of his support for Michel Aflaq and the Ba'athist National Command.
|-
| colspan="10"| Vacant ( – )
|-
! 16
|
| Nureddin al-Atassi
| —
| 25 February 1966
| 18 November 1970
|
! style="background:;" |
| Syrian Ba'ath Party
| Atassi was overthrown when a falling out occurred between Salah Jadid, the country's de facto leader from 1966 to 1970 as Assistant Regional Secretary of the Regional Command, and Hafez al-Assad, the Minister of Defense. Assad initiated a coup in 1970, known as the Corrective Movement.
|-style="background-color:#E6E6AA"
| —
|
| Ahmad al-Khatib
| —
| 18 November 1970
| 12 March 1971
|
! style="background:;" |
| Syrian Ba'ath Party
| Assad served as the country's de facto leader during this period, as head of the Temporary Regional Command and as Regional Secretary of the Regional Command; and from 22 February 1971 onwards additionally as Deputy Commander-in-Chief of the Army and Armed Forces.
|-
! 17
|
| Hafez al-Assad
| 19711978198519911999
| 12 March 1971
| 10 June 2000
|
! style="background:;" |
| Syrian Ba'ath Party
| In late 1983, due to deteriorating health, Assad transferred his powers during his absence and recovery to a committee consisting of members from his close circle. Assad recovered and died in office seventeen years later.
|-style="background-color:#E6E6AA"
| —
|
| Abdul Halim Khaddam
| —
| 10 June 2000
| 17 July 2000
|
! style="background:;" |
| Syrian Ba'ath Party
| Khaddam constitutionally succeeded from the vice presidency, and served on an acting basis until the new confirmative referendum.
|-
! 18
|
| Bashar al-Assad
| 2000200720142021
| 17 July 2000
| 8 December 2024
|
! style="background:;" |
| Syrian Ba'ath Party
| Assad was overthrown during the fall of Damascus in the Syrian civil war, and fled the country to Russia.
|-
| bgcolor=#EEEEEE colspan="10"| Transitional period (2024–present)
|-
| colspan="10"| Ahmed al-Sharaa served as the de facto Leader of Syria ( – )|||||
}} as the emir of the Hay'at Tahrir al-Sham, general commander and head of the new Syrian administration until 29 January 2025, when he was appointed President of Syria by the Syrian General Command.}}
|-
! 19
|
| Ahmed al-Sharaa
| —
| 29 January 2025
| Incumbent
|
! style="background:;" |
| Independent
| Al-Sharaa was appointed as president by the Syrian General Command during the transitional period at the Syrian Revolution Victory Conference.
|}
